Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2009 10:49AM digid wrote: OH my, I am glad to find this topic.  If I read "Thank God my nodes weren't involved" on other posts one more time, I may scream and bash my keyboard in.  I am 31 with a 4 year-old, with 2 positive level 1 nodes and HER2 positive status.  I had a bilateral mastecomy just over 2 weeks ago and am waiting for onc consult and chemo.  I need positive posts like all of yours to stay strong and be positive.  Bless you all.
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: digid wrote: Hi everyone- I am scheduled for my double mastectomy for Grade 2 IDC, DCIS and a positive sentinel lymph node tomorrow morning - Thursday, October 22 in Calgary, Canada.  If you have a moment during your day, please send me all the strength and love and hope you can muster.  I am 31 with a beautiful 4 year-old, and I will be strong and overcome.  But sharing the amazing spirits of all of you as I move through my fear can only help me be stronger.  Thank you and let us all be healthy and NED until we're old and cranky. In darkness, I find my inner light. Dx 10/14/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 2/21 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Send me your strength for Thursday, October 22 digid digid

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 08:59PM digid wrote: Thanks for the love everyone.  I came home Friday morning after only 1 day in the hospital (hurrah) and only OTC ibuprofen needed for pain!  Strangely, I felt very very calm for the first time in weeks as soon as I woke from my surgery.  Everything went "perfectly" according to my surgeon and the anaethestist let me wear my i pod shuffle of healing music for the whole surgery.  This really helped me. Plus the anaesthetist was incredibly good looking (lol).  Definitely a nice face to fall asleep too.  But waking up to my amazing husband's was even better.  Everyone at the hospital was so kind, respected my wishes about my diabetes care, and gave me my own room.  My pre-op nurses even came to see me before I left just to see that I was OK. Now I'm home with my dear dear husband who took off my dressings so gently today and empties my 3 drains as needed while tending our 4 year-old and doing the household chores.  I am very very blessed.  I have always been grateful for my life, but now I see all the love around me that I have always questioned because I didn't love myself enough.  I love my life, I love my body and I love every one of you that sent your words winging across the world when I was paralyzed by fear.  Thanks again, sisters.  I recommend "Sounds of Healing", an album by Jonathan Goldman (grab it off iTunes), to anyone going through and recovering from diagnosis and surgery.  I even wear my little iPod to sleep and it is SO relaxing.  Not my normal choice of tunes, but just right for now.  Erin
Posts.Title: Send me your strength for Thursday, October 22 digid digid

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2009 06:45PM digid wrote: Thanks everyone.  I got my drains out yesterday and I got to go to my daughter's preschool Hallowe'en party, which was great.  My scars are smooth and even so far, and I went and tried on fake boobs today which was a surprisingly lighhearted and entertaining experience.  I am getting stronger and more positive every day!  I love my strong body, I love my family, and I love my country for my single medical bill (which arrived yesterday): 24 Canadian dollars for the private room I elected to have at the hospital.  And they will pay for reconstruction after chemo if I want it!!  Oh beautiful ladies, it is strange how such a terrible diagnosis can arrive along with so much kindness and gratitude.  I was so suspicious and skeptical of people before, and my faith in the goodness of others is now very strong.  Thanks to each of you for helping to make that happen.  I hope your own journeys are blessed with equal compassion.
Posts.Title: Send me your strength for Thursday, October 22 digid digid

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2009 02:20PM digid wrote: Hi Wind2B, I was diagnosed with IDC and DCIS with sentinel node involvement ladt Thursday.  I am scheduled for a double simple mastectomy next Thursday.  I am 31 and I have had Type 1 diabetes for 19 years.  I have done some online research about your question already.  It's hard to find information, for sure!   This forum: http://www.steadyhealth.com/breast_cancer_and_type_1_diabetes_t101982.html has some discussion of chemo, steroids and BGs. http://tudiabetes.com/forum/topics/583967:Topic:206942?page=1&commentId=583967%3AComment%3A213369&x=1#583967Comment213369 This site also has some people who've gone through chemo while insulin-dependent.  I hope they help you.  Can I ask you how difficult the mastecomy made your diabetes care right afterwards?  Any advice for me would be greatly appreciated.  Hugs and hope.
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and Type I diabetes wind2B digid
